results.title: Daily life of the Bozo people
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation and Hermann Schlenker
results.brief_description: A documentary account of a typical day for the Bozo tribe in Mali, West Africa. Environmental demands are met through a classic division of labour determined in large part by the annual fluctuations of the River Niger. Shows the people as they wash, weave, fish, cook and eat. Without narration - natural sounds only.

results.title: Daily bread
results.brief_description: Although Britain grows grain, most of the flour needed to make the bread which feeds the people of the British Isles is imported from overseas. This film follows the processes of manufacture from the time that the flour is unloaded in the ports until it leaves the baker’s van in the delivery-man’s basket.

results.title: Daguerre: the birth of photography = Daguerre: ou la naissan
results.brief_description: Traces the early history of photography, concentrating on the achievements of Joseph Niepce, who in 1822 invented the first permanent photograph. Louis Daguerre, who in 1838, developed a process for recording photographs on polished metal plates is shown with other innovators in the field.
results.title_for_label: Daguerre: the birth of photography = Daguerre: ou la naissan

results.title: Daffy Duck's madcap mania
results.brief_description: A compilation of six animated cartoons starring the wacky Daffy Duck. Daffy has many sides to his personality and that’s what makes him so lovable, you never quite know what to expect. See him as Duck Drake - Private Eye, Ear, Nose and Throat in “The Super snooper” or dress up as a rooster to win $5000 in the Best Rooster competition in “You were never duckier” or even feel a wee bit sorry for Daffy as he plays Bugs Bunny’s double with great gusto only to find himself on the receiving end of disrespect from both Elmer Fudd and Yosemite Sam. Henery Hawk and George K. Chickenhawk also feature in “You were never duckier” and Porky Pig guest stars in “Daffy Duck hunt”, “Golden yeggs” and “Dime to retire”.

results.title: Dad and Dave: on our selection
results.creator_credit: ICON, Anthony Buckley Productions, AFFC, Anthony Buckley, Bruce Davey and George Whaley
results.brief_description: Steele Rudd’s classic Dad and Dave stories represent what is both noble and comic in colonial society. The Rudd’s are a loud, unconventional farming family, ekeing out a living in the harsh conditions of the bush with little respect for authority. Stereotypical “fair dinkum Aussies”, Dad’s blustering and Ma’s stoicism hold the family together. This film features the talents of an all-star cast including Leo McKern, Dame Joan Sutherland, Geoffrey Rush, Ray Barrett, Nicholas Eadie, Noah Taylor and Barry Otto, with songs and music by Peter Best.

results.title: Dad's house, mum's house
results.brief_description: Shared custody, co-parenting, share-parenting…it goes by different names. The children may move back and forth between parents, or one parent may retain day-to-day care…its form varies from family to family. Joint custody allows both parents to participate in major decisions affecting their child’s health, education and welfare.
results.description: Shared custody, co-parenting, share-parenting…it goes by different names. Joint custody allows both parents to participate in major decisions affecting their child’s health, education and welfare.

results.title: Dad's army: Turkey dinner. Ring dem bells. When you've got to go
results.brief_description: Popular comic English television program “Dad’s army”, which ran for nine years, is about numerous men that comprise the local division of the Home Guard in the seaside town of Walmington-on-Sea during World War 2. The men are an eccentric lot who range in age from the very young to the decidedly doddery. In each episode the group muddle their way through a different situation in their own idiosyncratic way. Episodes include: “Turkey dinner” (30 mins, 1974) When Corporal Jones is left holding a dead turkey after the platoon’s drunken night-watch, Mainwaring decides to treat the town’s senior citizens to a feast. “Ring dem bells” (30 mins, 1975) Mainwaring is not pleased when his platoon is chosen to play Nazis in an Army film and Pike is selected to play a German officer. “When you’ve got to go” (1975, 30 mins) Despite his bad chest, sinuses and weak ankles, Pike is passed A1 on his medical.

results.title: Dad's army: Is there honey still for tea? Come in your time is up. High Finance
results.brief_description: Popular comic English television program “Dad’s army”, which ran for nine years, is about numerous men that comprise the local division of the Home Guard in the seaside town of Walmington-on-Sea during World War 2. The men are an eccentric lot who range in age from the very young to the decidedly doddery. In each episode the group muddle their way through a different situation in their own idiosyncratic way. Episodes include: “Is there honey still for tea?” (1975, 30 mins) Private Godfrey’s cottage is condemned to be bulldozed because a new airstrip is to be built. “Come in your time is up” (1975, 31 mins) Mainwaring’s platoon discovers a German crew in a dinghy on a lake and endeavour to bring them to shore. “High finance” (1975, 31 mins) Mainwaring decides that Jones’ bank account has been in the red too long.

results.title: D.W. Griffith: father of film
results.creator_credit: Channel Four, Thames Television, Kevin Brownlow and David Gill
results.brief_description: A three part survey of the life and work of D.W. Griffith. His formative years in the theatre and at Biograph were followed by his major successes between 1915-1921: “The Birth of a nation”, “Broken blossoms”, “Way down east” and “Orphans of the storm”. The subsequently influential “Intolerance” was a critical and commercial failure prefiguring the failure, in the twenties, of “America”, “Isn’t life wonderful” and “The Sorrows of Satan” and later, of his neglected sound films, “Abraham Lincoln” and “The Struggle”. Brownlow and Gill make extensive use of colour-tinted extracts from his films and interviews with Lillian Gish, Blanche Sweet, Karl Brown and others. Narrated by Lindsay Anderson.

results.title: D.P.: Displaced Person
results.creator_credit: HTV, Barry Levinson and Alan Bridges
results.brief_description: Based on the story by Kurt Vonnegut Jnr, author of Breakfast of Champions and Slaughterhouse Five. It’s the aftermath of the world’s greatest war. Allied occupied Germany, ravaged and shamed in defeat, must now pick up the pieces. One of those pieces is a small black orphan boy named Tobias. Abandoned at a cold and dismal orphanage, he dreams - despite jeers from the other embittered children - of his courageous father’s return from war to claim him. When Tobias meets his first black man, he’s convinced the G.I. sergeant is the father of his dreams.
